comments.body: Silent skip on a failure seems bad. Why not fail or at least log on a failed lookup?

Hi Fabio,

That's not really a skip, nor a failure.

The test case wil try to bind an IPv6 by name. If no name is associated 
to ::1, the test does not run.

The cases of failure would be if in case of a failed lookup, and the 
test will

Le 22/04/15 22:40, Fabio Yeon a écrit :

> In pkg/client/portforward/portforward_test.go 
> https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/kubernetes/pull/7187#discussion_r28912507:
> 
> > @@ -253,6 +249,20 @@ func TestGetListener(t *testing.T) {
> >         },
> >     }
> > -   // On some linux systems, ::1 does not resolve to localhost but to localhost6 or
> > -   // ip6-localhost. To make the test case portable, we need to do a reverse lookup on ::1 and
> > -   // trying to bind a port with the name.
> > -   names, err := net.LookupAddr("::1")
> > -   if err == nil && len(names) > 0 {
> 
> Silent skip on a failure seems bad. Why not fail or at least log on a 
> failed lookup?
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub 
> https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/kubernetes/pull/7187/files#r28912507.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +259,263 @@		errorRaised := err != nil

		if testCase.ShouldRaiseError != errorRaised {
			t.Errorf("Test case #%d failed: Data %v an error has been raised(%t) where it should not (or reciprocally): %v", i, testCase, testCase.ShouldRaiseError, err)
			continue

comments.body: Sorry, I just noticed this - can you move this up to right before you call SplitHostPort and call it via defer?
Oh wait, that won't work because the same port is being reused.
